column1: Turlock is a city in Stanislaus County
column3: United States. Its estimated 2019 population of 73
column4: 631 made it the second-largest city in Stanislaus County after Modesto.

column3: by prominent grain farmer John William Mitchell
column4: the town consisted of a post office
column6: a grain warehouse and a few other buildings. Mitchell declined the honor of having the town named for himself. The name "Turlock" was then chosen instead. The name is believed to originate from the Irish village Turlough. In October 1870
column7: Harper's Weekly published an excerpt from English novelist James Payn's story Bred in the Bone
column8: which includes the mention of a town named "Turlough" (translated from Gaelic as "Turlock"). Local historians believe that the issue of Harper's Weekly was read by early resident H.W. Lander
column9: who suggested the alternate name.Mitchell and his brother were successful businessmen
column10: buying land and developing large herds of cattle and sheep that were sold to gold miners and others as they arrived. They were also leaders in wheat farming and cultivated tracts of land under the tenant system. Eventually
column11: the Mitchells owned most of the area
column14: from Keyes to Atwater. In the early 20th century
column15: 20-acre lots from the Mitchell estate were sold for $20 an acre.While it grew to be a relatively prosperous and busy hub of activity throughout the end of the 19th century
column16: it was not incorporated as a city until February 15
column17: 1908. By that time intensive agricultural development surrounded most of the city (agriculture remains the major economic force in the region in current times). Many of the initial migrants to the region were Swedish. As an early San Francisco Chronicle article stated of the region and the community's lacteal productivity
column18: "you have to hand it to the Scandinavians for knowing how to run a dairy farm."Turlock went on to become known as the "Heart of the Valley" because of its agricultural production. With the boom came racial and labor strife. In July 1921
column19: a mob of 150 white men evicted 60 Japanese cantaloupe pickers from rooming houses and ranches near Turlock
column20: taking them and their belongings on trucks out of town. The white men claimed the Japanese were undercutting white workers by taking lower wages per crate of fruit picked. In protest
column21: fruit growers briefly threatened not to hire the white workers behind the eviction
column22: preferring to let melons rot on vines to hiring such characters. As a result of this stance
column23: the eviction had the opposite effect of what the mob had intended. By August
column25: were nearly the only people employed to pick melons.The affair gained national attention
column26: and California Governor William Stephens vowed that justice would be served. Six men were quickly arrested but were apparently untroubled by the charges
column27: stating that leaders of Turlock's American Legion and Chamber of Commerce had told them that no trouble would come of their actions. Although a former Turlock night watchman testified that one of the accused had disclosed a plan "to clean up Turlock of the Japs
column28: all of the arrested were acquitted.The editorial line of the San Francisco Chronicle opposed both the evictions and Japanese labor, with one column stating that we in California are determined that Oriental workers shall be kept out of the state. But that does not mean that the decent citizens of California will tolerate for one moment such proceedings as the attack of a mob on the Japanese cantaloupe workers in the Turlock district."In 1930
column29: Turlock's population was 20% Assyrian. They were such a significant part of the population that the southern part of town even became referred to as Little Urmia
column30: referring to the region of northwestern Iran from most had come. In the 1930s
column31: Turlock was cited by Ripley's Believe It or Not as having the most churches per capita in the US
column32: which had partly to do with the variety of ethnic churches established for the relatively small settler population. Various religious centers reflecting a diverse population
column36: Mormon and Roman Catholic churches have been built.

column10: State Route 99 (formerly U.S. Route 99) was completed through the area
column11: largely bypassing the then-incorporated areas of Turlock in a route to the west of the city through mostly undeveloped land. Since that time
column12: the city has grown westward considerably to meet the [[freeway's north–south path
column13: but urban development west of the freeway has only recently begun to take hold. In an attempt to allow for orderly growth of the city
column14: comprehensive growth master plans have established urban growth boundaries since the 1960s.Turlock experienced extensive growth of both residential and commercial areas in the 1980s
column15: following a statewide boom in housing demand and construction. The housing boom of the 1980s diminished in the early 1990s but increased again in the second half of the decade
column16: partly as a result of San Francisco Bay Area growth
column17: which placed a higher demand for more affordable housing in outlying areas. After the dot-com bust
column19: producing higher house prices in an area formerly known for affordable housing. A recent boom in the retail sector has produced considerable growth along the Highway 99 corridor. The city reached its northern urban growth boundary
column22: and growth beyond it is restricted by the city's Master Plan.

column3: wet winters. Average January temperatures are a maximum of 53.7 °F (12.1 °C) and a minimum of 38.1 °F (3.4 °C). Average July temperatures are a maximum of 104.4 °F (40.2 °C) and a minimum of 62.6 °F (17.0 °C). There are an average of 78.0 days with highs of 90 °F (32 °C) or higher and an average of 19.8 days with lows of 32 °F (0 °C) or lower. The record high temperature was 114 °F (46 °C) on July 9
column4: 1896. The record low temperature was 18 °F (−8 °C) on January 21

column1: The average annual precipitation is 11.88 inches (302 mm). There are an average of 48 days with measurable precipitation.  The wettest year was 1983 with 27.03 inches (687 mm) and the dryest year was 1953 with 5.32 inches (135 mm). The most precipitation in one month was 8.47 inches (215 mm) in February 1998. The most precipitation in 24 hours was 2.70 inches (69 mm) on December 11
column2: 1906. Although snow is very rare in Turlock
column3: 3.0 inches (76 mm) fell in January 1922 and 2.0 inches (51 mm) fell in February 1976.

column2: the area is home to large concentrations of Americans of South Asian descent (particularly Sikhs)
column4: and people of varied European descent. Swedes and Portuguese were early settlers to the area. Continued immigration from the Azores Islands (Portugal) in recent decades has established a large Portuguese-speaking community within the city. Turlock is a major center for the Assyrian community in the United States
column5: who began to arrive in the 1910s seeking opportunities in farming. By 1924 the Assyrian Evangelical Church was established and by the 1950s
column6: 8% of the population of Turlock was Assyrian. There was an increased influx into Turlock in the 1970s following political strife in Iraq and in the 1980s following the 1979 Islamic Revolution in Iran.

column1: The indoor soccer team the Turlock Cal Express of the Major Arena Soccer League (MASL) plays at the Turlock Indoor Soccer Complex. Turlock is home to the California State University

column1: Turlock uses a Council–Manager form of government. It is led by a five-member City Council consisting of a Mayor
column3: and three Councilmembers. The Mayor is elected at-large
column4: while each Councilmember is elected to one of four electoral districts. All five Councilmembers are elected to four-year terms. The Turlock City Council holds public meetings every second and fourth Tuesday of each month at 6:00 p.m. City Hall is located at 156 South Broadway in Turlock. A directly elected City Treasurer also serves a four-year term.In the California State Legislature
column5: Turlock is in the  8th Senate District
column8: represented by Republican Heath Flora.In the United States House of Representatives
column9: Turlock is in California's  10th congressional district

column2: while Stanislaus Regional Transit also has routes in Turlock. An Altamont Corridor Express commuter rail station is planned to be constructed in Turlock for service starting in 2027. Amtrak serves Turlock at the nearby Denair station.
